[1]As far as con man stories go, I think I've heard them all. Of grifters, ropers, faro fixers, tales drawn long and tall. But if one bears a bookmark in the confidence man's tome, twould be that of Penelope, and of the brothers Bloom. 
[2]At ten and thirteen Bloom and Stephen 
[3]had been through several foster families. 
[4]Thirty eight, all told. 
[5]Mischief moved them on in life, and moving kept them close. 
[6]For Bloom had Stephen, Stephen Bloom, and both had more than most. 
[7]Another home, another main street. Stephen looked around, then summed the burgh up thusly: 
[8]One theater. One car wash. One cafe. One park. One cat. Which, through some mishap, had one leg. 
[9]One school, which meant one tight- knit group of local well-off kids. 
[10]Their pocket-change bought rocket pops,

[13]Always there. In every town. 
[14]Could he simply 
[15]Just drop his fears and go? Leave his brother in the woods, and join the children? 
[16]No. 
[17]This wasn't really true. Cause in the root of Stephen's psyche, something now began. A seed of grand epiphany. A hook. A tale. 
[18]A fiction made for profit, in which both boys played a part. A simple con in fifteen steps. 
[19]And then, as if a curtain had been pulled back from the sky... Some barrier within the younger Bloom was broken. 
[20]So Bloom performed his role in Stephen's story to a T. 
[21]And being who he wasn't, could be as he wished to be. 
[22]Must the numbers rattle on?    Must the fiction end?

[28]But the moment passed. 
[29]They didn't catch the will-o-wisp, but didn't really care. 
[30]Our fledgling thieves were satisfied. 
[31]The children's parents, less so.

[33]The brothers Bloom had found their calling.

dialogues.Charleston:
[1]Cause the Turk was right. After seeing her, after that night on the airstrip, after Cairo everything changed, and he couldn't see the play through that one milky eye, but the Turk was right about one thing, that there's nothing beautiful about money. She's beautiful. 
[2]He'll never have her now. She's free. And I'll never see her in scarlet again, her chestnut hair, but it's worth the money and my job and his life and the rest of my life that she's free. 
[3]You're not here. Neither of us are. It's Mowcher's gun. 
[4]They won't find him for a week, and the Albino will chalk it up to Davey, he won't talk. We're clean. 
[5]The man named Charleston you met nine months and a thousand years ago at the hotel bar in Jodhpur is dead. If we see each other again it'll be as strangers. As for the money... let it rot.
